questions.question_text: A wireless engineer is designing a wireless network to support real time applications over wireless. Which IEEE protocol must the engineer enable on the WLC so that the number of packets that are exchanged between an access point and client are reduced and fast roaming occurs?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
According to Cisco ENWLSD course, it is B.

Selected Answer: B
it explained the reason below.
https://documentation.meraki.com/MR/Wi-Fi_Basics_and_Best_Practices/802.11k_and_802.11r_Overview

Selected Answer: B
I read, googled and asked a Cisco expert, they all say 802.11R. This is important :"Reduces the number of packets that are exchanged between the client and an AP"

Selected Answer: B
802.11r skips the EAPoL packages.
802.11k is an ammendment that the AP helps the client choosing a new AP to roam to, but the roaming procedure itself won't change.

comments.content: 802.11k is an amendment that the AP helps the client choosing a new AP to roam to (it provides a list), but the roaming procedure itself won't change.
I think you should validate and not speculate. Its clearly B 802.11r

discussion.content: Provided answer is correct, K setting allows for the removal of real time re-authentication between access points.
B is the correct answer

802.11r reduces the number of packets that are exchanged between the client and an AP. This means the roam itself occurs faster because the AP already has the client authentication credentials cached, resulting in fewer packets required between the client and the AP.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/Enterprise/Mobility/RToWLAN/CCVP_BK_R7805F20_00_rtowlan-srnd/CCVP_BK_R7805F20_00_rtowlan-srnd_chapter_0101.html

questions.question_text: How are mobility groups created, excluding mobility anchors?

comments.content: The Group Name is inherited from the Default Mobility Domain Name

discussion.content:
Answer A is correct

To create a Mobility Group, you just add WLCs to the Mobility Group Member list (of each WLC). WLCs with the same Group Name will end up in the same Mobility Group. 
If you add WLCs with a different Group Name to the list, they will form a different Mobility Group, but end up in the same Mobility Domain. The Mobility Domain can contain up to 3 Mobility Groups.

A is correct , as B. is wrong , each WLC in WLC HA pair cannot be considered separately as a mobility peer, physically they are 2 WLCs, but from function point of view, in Mobility group you should consider them as one.
C. is wrong, the WLCs do not have to be of the same model or type to be member of mobility group.but to be functional the should run same software version.
D. is wrong as all WLCs in mobility group should use same virtual IP address.

Selected Answer: A
Answer: A

Selected Answer: A
Answer A with the correction commented by others.
None of the answers a true but it seems like there is a mistake in the A answer. If you replace "domain" with "group" - that would be true.

comments.content:
"Each WLC must use the same Mobility Domain name and be defined as a peer in each other’s Static Mobility Members list. The exception to this rule are when guest anchors are deployed where Cisco recommends deploying a separate Mobility Group for the guest anchors". Enterprise Mobility 8.5 Design Guide, Ch2, p2-57
If you go to WLC GUI and click the Controller tab you will see the Default Mobility Domain Name field. I think it's what is meant.
If you check further this guide on the p 10-20 you will see the phrase
 "The "Group Name" in Figure 10-13 above is the name configured under the foreign WLC's 'Default Mobility Domain Name'". 
They mixed up 2 concepts in that guide and in the Official Cert Guide and they didn't write in the Official Cert Guide that to assign a WLC to mobility group you need to fill the Default Mobility Domain Name field.
So A is correct for sure

Think A is correct but its not precise. According to Cisco book: mobility domain - A logical grouping of all mobility groups within an enterprise. So in theory the WLC can be on different mobility groups BUT on the same mobility domain. Hence, A is correct, however is not precise because to being called peers they should be on the same mobility group. Its the best answer of this 4 imo.

choices.C: The WLCs do not have to be of the same model or type to be a member of a mobility group; however, each member should be running different software versions.
choices.D: A mobility group does not require all WLCs in the group to use the same virtual IP address.
choices.A: Each WLC must use the same mobility domain name and be defined as a peer in each other's static mobility members list.
choices.B: If WLCs with HA SSO are deployed, each WLC in the WLC HA pair is considered separately as a mobility peer.

choices.D: Roaming occurs when the phone has reached גˆ’80 dBs or below.
choices.A: Full reauthentication introduces gaps in a voice conversation.
choices.B: Roaming time increases when using 802.1x + Cisco Centralized Key Management.
choices.E: Roaming with only 802.1x authentication requires full reauthentication.
choices.C: Roaming occurs when the phone has seen at least four APs.

discussion.content: when we use 802.11 with CCKM or Fast secure roaming , then the time of roaming is shorter compare to 802.11 only
A and E are correct choice , since the rest choice are incorrect.

questions.question_text: Which two considerations must a network engineer have when planning for voice over wireless roaming? (Choose two.)
When conducting a site survey for real-time traffic over wireless, which two design capabilities of smartphones and tablets must be considered? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Answer: C y E

"Most smartphones and tablets support 802.11. However, generally, the smartphones and tablets have fewer antennas and lower data rates than laptops"


https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/Enterprise/Mobility/RToWLAN/CCVP_BK_R7805F20_00_rtowlan-srnd/CCVP_BK_R7805F20_00_rtowlan-srnd_chapter_01.html

Selected Answer: CE
C and E are the correct answer.
I would say C and E

Selected Answer: CE
Smartphones and tablets typically have fewer antennas and lower data rates compared to laptops.

Selected Answer: CE
Smart phones have fewer antennas and lower data rates than laptops

Selected Answer: CE
lower data rates and smaller antennas

Selected Answer: CE
C and E
Answer: A y D

Is Wi-Fi faster on phone or laptop?
The reason why Wi-Fi is faster on a smartphone than on that computer is obvious. It's clearly not equipped with the hardware to be able to connect at this speed. The item that does not allow us to do this is a Wi-Fi network adapter for your desktop or laptop computer.

the smartphones and tablets have fewer antennas and lower data rates than laptops. In addition, most are not purpose-built for the enterprise WLAN market. Almost all smartphones and tablets support enterprise security policies
C&E

I think the correct answer is A&D
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/Enterprise/Mobility/RToWLAN/CCVP_BK_R7805F20_00_rtowlan-srnd/CCVP_BK_R7805F20_00_rtowlan-srnd_chapter_01.html
B & E are correct

Correct answer is C

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/9800/config-guide/b_wl_16_10_cg/mobility.html

"The Cisco Catalyst 9800 Series Wireless Controller mobility tunnel is a CAPWAP tunnel with control path (UDP 16666) and data path (UDP 16667). The control path is DTLS encypted by default. Data path DTLS can be enabled when you add the mobility peer."

Selected Answer: C
correct answer is C

Selected Answer: C
Answer C.

Selected Answer: C
C. is correct.

Given Answer is correct!

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless/catalyst-9800-series-wireless-controllers/213913-building-mobility-tunnels-on-catalyst-98.html

"On the 9800 WLC, control plane encryption is always enabled, which means that you need to have secure mobility enabled on the AireOS side. However, data link encryption is optional. If you enable it on the 9800 side, enable it on AireOS with: config mobility group member data-dtls enable"
Answer: C

The Cisco Catalyst 9800 Series Wireless Controller mobility tunnel is a CAPWAP tunnel with control path (UDP 16666) and data path (UDP 16667). The control path is DTLS encypted by default. Data path DTLS can be enabled when you add the mobility peer.

it should be C
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/9800/config-guide/b_wl_16_10_cg/mobility.html

choices.B: It is a CAPWAP tunnel with data path only.
choices.A: It is an IPsec tunnel with control path only.
choices.D: It is an IPsec tunnel with control path and data path.
choices.C: It is a CAPWAP tunnel with control path and data path.

questions.question_text: What is the 9800 Series Wireless Controller mobility tunnel on a Cisco Catalyst 9800 controller?
